name: NPR
text: Only a few hours left before Giving Tuesday is over. Make sure you do your part to support the journalism that matters to you by donating to your local NPR station. https://t.co/LzgHFrLiTo https://t.co/wFSonnNWTu

name: NPR
text:
Kurt Papenfus is the lone full-time emergency room doctor in the town of 900, not far from the Kansas line. 

His illness is a test case for how the pandemic is affecting the fragile rural healthcare system. https://t.co/Aq9AlanPGx

name: NPR
text: RT @EmilyZFeng: A few weeks ago I met the man who delivers my many Taobao packages. He was terrified. It was then that I began learning about the demanding, mobile app-tracked life of China’s 3 million delivery workers https://t.co/U2zkT90dQR

name: NPR
text:
Eastern Europe's populist leaders — particularly the increasingly authoritarian governments of Hungary and Poland — are having a hard time accepting that President Trump lost.
 https://t.co/Fob6o3Qu5K

name: NPR
text:
The Arecibo Observatory has collapsed. 

Once the world's largest single-dish radio telescope, it was used to detect the first binary pulsar in 1974 — a discovery that bolstered a key idea in Einstein's general theory of relativity.
https://t.co/6vOCtsFAEL

name: NPR
text:
NEW: The Justice Dept. is investigating a possible secret scheme involving a bribe in exchange for a presidential pardon, according to heavily redacted court documents unsealed Tuesday.
https://t.co/777NBo6Agp

name: NPR
text:
A new report suggests, on average, online learning in the pandemic has had little impact on kids' reading growth and has only somewhat slowed gains in math.

But a worrying caveat: Many of the nation's most vulnerable students are missing from the data.
https://t.co/Xs6D2pFULE

name: NPR
text:
A recent government report called the coal mine safety standard regulating deadly silica dust "out of date" and difficult to enforce. The Biden administration may finally change that standard.
https://t.co/HKwv2AcrRx

name: NPR
text:
At her Tiny Desk from Germany, the provocative soprano Julia Bullock delivers songs of introspection and freedom — from Franz Schubert's mountaintop epiphany to Billy Taylor's wish for equality and justice.
https://t.co/eyyj4pdBuU

name: NPR
text: Enough doomscrolling! Time to read a book. Here are about 2,500 suggestions: https://t.co/1toHxb1Ktn

name: NPR
text: Britain has become the first Western country to approve Pfizer's coronavirus vaccine for emergency use. It could be dispersed within days to the neediest people, government officials said. https://t.co/95qn7lk5WO

name: NPR
text:
A settlement between the U.S. Soccer Federation and the Women's National Team over working conditions will lead to an improvement in hotel accommodations, venues and travel.

A dispute over pay has yet to be resolved.
https://t.co/4vslS7q1Ff

name: NPR
text:
Gabriel Sterling, a Republican election official in Georgia, had strong words for President Trump and other Republican leaders who have made baseless claims of voter fraud in the state.
"It has all gone too far. All of it."  https://t.co/c8KqY5XoOJ

name: NPR
text:
Brittany Diaz is a traveling ICU nurse. She worked through the first crush of pandemic patients in New York, and another now in Texas. 

She's furious at people who compare it to the flu. "I've never seen a flu patient as sick as a COVID patient." @KUAF https://t.co/n1G6XzJtx6

name: NPR
text: Delivery workers are critical to China's courier services, which ship more than 60 billion packages a year. But for the people doing this grueling work, "The rewards are light, but the punishments are always heavy." https://t.co/KemuUWU7MH

name: NPR
text:
It's here: NPR Music's list of the 50 best albums of 2020. It's ranked, and it's spectacular.
https://t.co/M0LX0GyXu8

name: NPR
text:
The captain of a dive boat that caught fire last year off the coast of Santa Barbara was indicted Tuesday on 34 counts of negligent manslaughter.

The blaze killed 33 passengers and one crew member.
https://t.co/ubb28L2KEn

name: NPR
text:
President Trump is threatening to veto a critical defense spending bill unless Congress agrees to repeal Section 230, which protects tech companies from being held legally responsible for what users post.
https://t.co/Xu9HZtjZQq

name: NPR
text:
A new survey finds enrollment by international students in U.S. colleges has plummeted.

The pandemic is a major reason — but some experts point out that international student enrollment has been declining since 2016.
https://t.co/6Uxxlx6Nfe

name: NPR
text:
RT @Roughly: Naji always believed that in America, he could escape the war that defined his childhood and just feel safe again.

Did his family make the right choice? A story from @JakeHalpern and Michael Sloan’s graphic novel, “Welcome to the New World.” @HenryHolt

https://t.co/YhyvySpBes https://t.co/Io1qHSjuAm

name: NPR
text:
In revised guidelines, the CDC has trimmed its recommended quarantine time for possible coronavirus exposure — down from 14 days to 7-10 days, depending on test results and symptoms.
https://t.co/RzUJztLaJU

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: Jazz Standard, a perennial favorite venue for musicians and fans alike, has shut its doors. It's the first major jazz club in New York City to close permanently due to the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/1OPDt6Yv18

name: NPR
text:
In a race with historic turnout, President-elect Joe Biden beat President Trump by nearly 7 million votes, and 74 votes in the Electoral College.

But his victory really was stitched together with narrow margins in a handful of swing states.
https://t.co/cwl4skIQ6d

name: NPR
text:
A preemptive presidential pardon isn't common, but it has happened — like Ford's pardon of Nixon. An expert says Trump could do so for those close to him and "be on firm legal ground."

"The really unclear scenario" would be if he tried to pardon himself. https://t.co/kYIhQvcZw6

name: NPR
text:
Social distancing "decreased dramatically" over the summer and into the fall, a new survey finds.

For example, reports of Americans going to a café, bar, or restaurant more than tripled, from 5% in April to 15.9% in November. 

A look at the trends 👇 https://t.co/iGkSeI2FOx https://t.co/RUOlRxUgoP

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprpolitics: Democrat Mark Kelly has been officially sworn in as a new senator from Arizona.

Kelly's term, which finishes the term of the late GOP Sen. John McCain, will end in 2022. https://t.co/1rqIGAZG08

name: NPR
text:
Opinion: After four years of Trump's unrelenting attacks on norms and institutions, both domestic and foreign, America is going to have to persuade others that it can lead again, say foreign policy experts Aaron David Miller and Richard Sokolsky.
https://t.co/zIsAaUebgX
